title: Lamentations Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Lamentations chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Lamentations Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Lamentations Chapter 2.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:1, what did the Lord cover the daughter of Zion with in His anger?
options: A cloud
Fire
Darkness
Smoke
questions.correctAnswer: A cloud
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:1 states that the Lord covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in His anger.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:2, what has the Lord swallowed up?
options: All the habitations of Jacob
The waters of the sea
The mountains of Judah
The sun and the moon
questions.correctAnswer: All the habitations of Jacob
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:2 says the Lord hath swallowed up all the habitations of Jacob and showed no pity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Lamentations 2:3, the Lord burned against Jacob like a gentle rain.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:3 states the Lord burned against Jacob like a flaming fire, not a gentle rain.

questions.question: What did the Lord bend like an enemy according to Lamentations 2:4?
options: His bow
His sword
His shield
His spear
questions.correctAnswer: His bow
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:4 says the Lord hath bent His bow like an enemy.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:5, who did the Lord swallow up?
options: Israel
Egypt
Babylon
Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:5 states the Lord was as an enemy and hath swallowed up Israel.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Lamentations 2:6: 'The Lord hath caused the solemn feasts and ______ to be forgotten in Zion.'
options: Sabbaths
Prayers
Offerings
Songs
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbaths
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:6 states that the Lord caused the solemn feasts and sabbaths to be forgotten in Zion.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 2:7 mentions that the Lord abhorred His sanctuary and cast off His altar.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:7 clearly says the Lord hath cast off His altar and abhorred His sanctuary.

questions.question: What did the LORD purpose to destroy in Lamentations 2:8?
options: The wall of the daughter of Zion
The temple of Babylon
The city of Moab
The mountains of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: The wall of the daughter of Zion
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:8 says the LORD purposed to destroy the wall of the daughter of Zion.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:9, where are the king and princes of the daughter of Zion?
options: Among the Gentiles
In the temple
In the wilderness
In captivity in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Among the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:9 states the king and princes are among the Gentiles.

questions.question: How do the elders of the daughter of Zion sit according to Lamentations 2:10?
options: Upon the ground
On thrones
In silence
In the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Upon the ground
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:10 says that the elders of the daughter of Zion sit upon the ground and keep silence.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 2:11 describes the speaker's eyes failing with tears because of the destruction of the daughter of his people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:11 states the speaker's eyes fail with tears for the destruction of the daughter of the people.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:12, what do the children ask their mothers when they swoon in the streets?
options: Where is corn and wine?
Where is bread and water?
Where is shelter?
Where is the Lord?
questions.correctAnswer: Where is corn and wine?
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:12 says children say to their mothers, 'Where is corn and wine?' when they swooned.

questions.question: What did the prophets see for the daughter of Jerusalem according to Lamentations 2:14?
options: Vain and foolish things
Visions of hope
The coming Messiah
Peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Vain and foolish things
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:14 says the prophets have seen vain and foolish things for the daughter of Jerusalem.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Lamentations 2:15: 'All that pass by clap their hands at thee; they hiss and wag their head at the daughter of ______.'
options: Jerusalem
Zion
Judah
Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:15 mentions 'the daughter of Jerusalem' as the one being mocked by passersby.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:17, what has the LORD fulfilled?
options: His word that he had commanded in the days of old
A new covenant
A promise of peace
A vision of restoration
questions.correctAnswer: His word that he had commanded in the days of old
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:17 states the LORD hath fulfilled his word that he had commanded in the days of old.

medium.title: Lamentations Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Lamentations Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Lamentations 2, what biblical truth would you share about God's discipline and faithfulness?
options: God’s anger is a sign of His justice but He remembers His covenant and can restore
God has forgotten His people and will not show mercy
God is indifferent to human suffering
God’s discipline is permanent and unchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger is a sign of His justice but He remembers His covenant and can restore
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:1 talks about God’s anger covering Zion like a cloud, but the chapter also implies God’s sovereign control and purpose in discipline (2:17, 2:22). This shows His justice but leaves room for hope in His covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Lamentations 2 teach us about the importance of prayer and lament in times of distress?
options: We should cry out to God persistently and pour out our hearts before Him
We should remain silent and accept our suffering without complaint
We should only pray once and then move on
Lamentation is discouraged in the Bible
questions.correctAnswer: We should cry out to God persistently and pour out our hearts before Him
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:18-19 encourages persistent crying out and pouring out the heart like water before the Lord, showing the biblical model of prayer and lament in hardship.

questions.question: A believer struggles with despair over sin and its consequences. According to Lamentations 2, what warning can be given about false prophecy and ignoring sin?
options: False prophets fail to reveal sin and lead to captivity
Sin has no consequences and can be ignored
Prophets always please the people with positive messages
God does not hold people accountable for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets fail to reveal sin and lead to captivity
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:14 states that the prophets saw vain things and did not discover iniquity to turn away captivity, illustrating the danger of ignoring sin and false teaching.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 2 teach about humility and recognizing God’s sovereignty during trials?
options: We must acknowledge God’s hand in discipline and not rely on our own strength
We should blame others and refuse to submit to God’s will
God’s sovereignty is a myth and has no impact on trials
Trials are random and have no spiritual significance
questions.correctAnswer: We must acknowledge God’s hand in discipline and not rely on our own strength
questions.explanation: Verses 17, 21, and 22 emphasize God’s purposeful actions in judgment and discipline, teaching believers to submit humbly to His sovereignty.

questions.question: How does Lamentations 2 instruct us about the role of leaders like priests and prophets in a godly community?
options: Leaders must faithfully reveal God’s truth and repent to prevent destruction
Leaders are unimportant and have no spiritual responsibility
Leaders should only seek popularity and avoid difficult truths
Leaders can ignore sin without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must faithfully reveal God’s truth and repent to prevent destruction
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:6-7 and 2:14 show that God despised the king and priest in anger and that false prophets failed to reveal sin, underscoring the responsibility of leaders to guide rightly.

questions.question: In the context of Lamentations 2, what practical advice would you give to a believer struggling with loss and mourning?
options: Express grief openly before God and seek His help in prayer
Suppress emotions and avoid talking about the pain
Ignore loss and pretend everything is fine
Seek comfort only from human sources
questions.correctAnswer: Express grief openly before God and seek His help in prayer
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 describe elders and virgins mourning with sackcloth and dust, showing that biblical mourning involves open expression and turning to God.

questions.question: How does Lamentations 2 show the importance of trusting God’s timing in trials and restoration?
options: God fulfills His word in His appointed time, even in judgment
God acts randomly without a plan
Restoration happens only if we deserve it
God forgets His promises when we sin
questions.correctAnswer: God fulfills His word in His appointed time, even in judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 17 says the Lord has done what He devised and fulfilled His word from ancient days, teaching trust in God’s sovereign timing.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is highlighted by the elders and virgins casting dust on their heads and wearing sackcloth in Lamentations 2?
options: Humility and repentance before God
Pride and self-reliance
Indifference to sin
Joy and celebration
questions.correctAnswer: Humility and repentance before God
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:10 describes these actions as signs of mourning and humility, teaching believers to repent and humble themselves in hardship.

questions.question: How does Lamentations 2 advise believers to respond when facing enemies who mock and rejoice over their suffering?
options: Call upon the Lord with persistent prayer and lament
Seek revenge and retaliation
Ignore the situation and remain silent
Join in mocking others
questions.correctAnswer: Call upon the Lord with persistent prayer and lament
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 describe enemies rejoicing and mocking, but verses 18-19 urge crying out to God persistently, showing prayer as the biblical response.

questions.question: True or False: According to Lamentations 2, the destruction and suffering experienced are results of God’s wrath due to persistent sin.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Multiple verses (2:3, 2:5, 2:17) clearly show God’s fierce anger and wrath as the cause of destruction, linking it to sin and disobedience.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 2 encourages believers to ignore their pain and not express grief openly before God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 and 18-19 show the importance of openly expressing grief and crying out to God, encouraging lamentation as part of faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Lamentations 2:4 says God "hath bent his bow like an enemy" and "poured out his fury like ______."
options: fire
water
wind
earthquake
questions.correctAnswer: fire
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:4 uses the imagery of God pouring out His fury like fire, symbolizing intense judgment and purification.

questions.question: How does Lamentations 2 demonstrate the importance of integrity and honesty for leaders in the community?
options: Leaders must confront sin honestly to prevent downfall
Leaders can hide sin to maintain peace
Leaders are not accountable for their actions
Leaders should only focus on political power
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must confront sin honestly to prevent downfall
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 6-7 show that false prophets and despised priests contributed to the downfall, highlighting the need for honest leadership.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2, what does the destruction of the temple and altar teach believers about stewardship and reverence for God’s house?
options: Neglect and sin can lead to loss of God’s presence and blessing
The temple is unimportant and can be ignored
God’s house is immune to human sin
Reverence is only a personal matter, not communal
questions.correctAnswer: Neglect and sin can lead to loss of God’s presence and blessing
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 show God despising His sanctuary and altar due to sin, teaching the importance of reverence and stewardship.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 2 teach about persevering in faith when the law and prophecy seem silent?
options: Believers must continue to trust and cry out to God even when guidance is unclear
Abandon faith because God no longer speaks
Ignore spiritual disciplines
Depend entirely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must continue to trust and cry out to God even when guidance is unclear
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states the law is no more and prophets find no vision, yet verses 18-19 encourage ongoing prayer and lament, teaching perseverance.

hard.title: Lamentations Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Lamentations Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:1, what metaphor is used to describe the Lord's anger towards Zion?
options: A cloud covering the daughter of Zion
A roaring lion attacking the city
A flood sweeping away the land
A burning furnace consuming the people
questions.correctAnswer: A cloud covering the daughter of Zion
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:1 depicts the Lord's anger as covering Zion like a cloud, symbolizing a divine judgment overshadowing and bringing devastation.

questions.question: Which phrase from Lamentations 2:3 symbolizes the Lord’s fierce and consuming anger?
options: A flaming fire which devoureth round about
A mighty tempest shaking the lands
A sword cutting through the nations
A lion roaring in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: A flaming fire which devoureth round about
questions.explanation: The verse uses the image of a consuming flame to emphasize the intensity and completeness of God's judgment on Jacob (Israel).

questions.question: What does the 'horn of Israel' in Lamentations 2:3 represent, and what happened to it?
options: The strength and power of Israel; it was cut off in God's fierce anger
The temple’s altar; it was desecrated by enemies
The royal scepter; it was taken by foreign kings
The covenant promise; it was annulled
questions.correctAnswer: The strength and power of Israel; it was cut off in God's fierce anger
questions.explanation: The 'horn' is a biblical symbol for strength and power; Lamentations 2:3 says God cut off all the horn of Israel, indicating the loss of power and blessing.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:6, what cultural and religious practices were forgotten in Zion because of the Lord's anger?
options: Solemn feasts and sabbaths
Circumcision and Passover
Prayer and fasting
Sacrifices and offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Solemn feasts and sabbaths
questions.explanation: The verse states that the Lord caused solemn feasts and sabbaths to be forgotten, indicating a disruption in religious observance.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'the altar' and 'sanctuary' being cast off and abhorred as described in Lamentations 2:7?
options: It symbolizes the loss of divine presence and worship
It indicates the temple was physically relocated
It shows the altar was replaced by idols
It means the priests were promoted to kings
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the loss of divine presence and worship
questions.explanation: The rejection of the altar and sanctuary in verse 7 reflects a theological statement about God withdrawing His presence due to Israel's sin and judgment.

questions.question: How does the depiction of the city gates in Lamentations 2:9 contribute to the theme of destruction?
options: The gates are sunk into the ground, symbolizing ruin and loss of security
The gates are adorned with gold, indicating restored glory
The gates are guarded by angels, showing divine protection
The gates are open wide to welcome foreigners
questions.correctAnswer: The gates are sunk into the ground, symbolizing ruin and loss of security
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes the gates as sunk into the ground, which metaphorically illustrates the city's fallen state and defenselessness.

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Lamentations 2:10, where elders sit silently on the ground with dust on their heads and virgins hang down their heads?
options: Parallelism emphasizing grief and mourning
Allegory portraying spiritual blindness
Chiasm illustrating the reversal of fortunes
Hyperbole exaggerating the city's destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism emphasizing grief and mourning
questions.explanation: The verse uses parallel images of sorrowful elders and virgins to emphasize the communal mourning through parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:13, the breach of the daughter of Jerusalem is compared to what natural element, and what does this imply about her condition?
options: The sea; implying vast and overwhelming damage
A mountain; implying something immovable
A desert; implying barrenness
A forest; implying wildness
questions.correctAnswer: The sea; implying vast and overwhelming damage
questions.explanation: The verse compares the breach to the sea, a vast and uncontrollable force, highlighting the extent of Jerusalem’s destruction.

questions.question: What error did the prophets commit according to Lamentations 2:14?
options: They saw vain and foolish things and did not discover iniquity to turn captivity
They predicted immediate restoration instead of destruction
They promoted idolatry among the people
They refused to speak against the kings
questions.correctAnswer: They saw vain and foolish things and did not discover iniquity to turn captivity
questions.explanation: Verse 14 criticizes the prophets for failing to recognize the people's sins and thus not preventing their exile.

questions.question: How do the enemies react to Jerusalem’s destruction in Lamentations 2:15, and what irony is present in their taunt?
options: They clap and hiss, ironically calling it 'The perfection of beauty'
They mourn silently, showing respect
They flee in fear, fearing divine wrath
They offer peace treaties, seeking alliance
questions.correctAnswer: They clap and hiss, ironically calling it 'The perfection of beauty'
questions.explanation: The enemies mock Jerusalem’s downfall by sarcastically referring to it as a city once renowned for beauty, highlighting bitter irony.

questions.question: Lamentations 2:17 states the Lord fulfilled His word from 'the days of old.' What biblical concept does this reflect?
options: Divine covenant faithfulness even in judgment
Random punishment without warning
Human free will without divine intervention
The futility of prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: Divine covenant faithfulness even in judgment
questions.explanation: The verse underscores that God’s judgment is consistent with His ancient promises, showing His faithfulness to His word.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:19, what action is the daughter of Zion urged to take, and what is the theological significance of this plea?
options: Arise and cry out in the night; it signifies earnest prayer and lamentation before God
Build new walls; it indicates human effort to restore security
Offer sacrifices; it shows ritual atonement
Go into exile; it represents obedience to judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Arise and cry out in the night; it signifies earnest prayer and lamentation before God
questions.explanation: The call to cry out in the watches of the night represents deep, ongoing lament and petition, a biblical motif for seeking God’s mercy.

questions.question: True or False: According to Lamentations 2:20, the women and children were spared during the destruction of Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 20 questions if women will eat their own children and if priests and prophets are slain, indicating that none were spared.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'none escaped nor remained' in Lamentations 2:22 suggest about the nature of the judgment?
options: Total and comprehensive destruction with no survivors
Partial destruction with some survivors
A metaphorical judgment without physical harm
A future prophecy yet to be fulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: Total and comprehensive destruction with no survivors
questions.explanation: The phrase emphasizes the completeness of the devastation, indicating that all who were nurtured were consumed by the enemy.

questions.question: How does the depiction of the Lord's hand in Lamentations 2:8 function within the chapter's literary structure?
options: It symbolizes unstoppable divine judgment stretching out to destroy the city
It represents human rebellion against God
It indicates God’s protection over Jerusalem
It is a metaphor for the city’s rebuilding efforts
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes unstoppable divine judgment stretching out to destroy the city
questions.explanation: The 'stretched out hand' in verse 8 is a vivid image of God's active and relentless judgment, contributing to the chapter’s theme of inevitable destruction.

theological.title: Lamentations Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Lamentations Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:1, how has the Lord manifested His anger towards the daughter of Zion?
options: Covered her with a cloud and cast down the beauty of Israel from heaven
Sent a flood to wash away the land
Allowed foreign nations to prosper
Removed the temple priests
questions.correctAnswer: Covered her with a cloud and cast down the beauty of Israel from heaven
questions.explanation: Lamentations 2:1 states that the Lord covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in His anger and cast down the beauty of Israel from heaven, indicating divine judgment. This aligns with Isaiah 64:6-7, Jeremiah 25:38, Ezekiel 22:31, and Hebrews 12:29, which speak of God's righteous wrath and judgment.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 2:3 describe as being cut off in God's fierce anger?
options: All the horn of Israel
The roots of the olive tree
The branches of David
The walls of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: All the horn of Israel
questions.explanation: The 'horn' is a biblical symbol of strength and power (1 Samuel 2:10, Psalm 18:2, Habakkuk 3:4). Lamentations 2:3 says God cut off all the horn of Israel in His fierce anger, showing the removal of Israel's power and protection due to sin and judgment.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:4, how is God's action described toward those pleasant to the eye in the tabernacle of Zion?
options: He stood as an adversary and slew them
He protected and preserved them
He blessed them abundantly
He ignored their plight
questions.correctAnswer: He stood as an adversary and slew them
questions.explanation: Verse 4 depicts God as an adversary who stood with His right hand to slay those pleasant in Zion's tabernacle, illustrating divine judgment on what was once beloved, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:39, Ezekiel 9:6, Amos 3:2, and Romans 11:22.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 2:6 say was caused to be forgotten in Zion by the LORD's anger?
options: Solemn feasts and sabbaths
The law and the prophets
The prayers and offerings
The kings and warriors
questions.correctAnswer: Solemn feasts and sabbaths
questions.explanation: The destruction led to the forgetting of solemn feasts and sabbaths (Lamentations 2:6), signifying broken covenant worship. This echoes the importance of these observances in Exodus 20:8-11, Leviticus 23, Nehemiah 13:15-22, and Hebrews 4:9-10.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:7, what has the Lord done to His altar and sanctuary?
options: He hath cast off His altar and abhorred His sanctuary
He hath consecrated them anew
He hath expanded their borders
He hath filled them with glory
questions.correctAnswer: He hath cast off His altar and abhorred His sanctuary
questions.explanation: Verse 7 explains God's rejection of His altar and sanctuary due to Israel's sin, showing the severity of judgment. Similar themes appear in Ezekiel 10:18, Psalm 74:7, Isaiah 1:11-13, and Hebrews 8:13 regarding God's rejection when covenant faithfulness is broken.

questions.question: What is the condition of the gates and bars of the daughter of Zion in Lamentations 2:9?
options: Her gates are sunk into the ground and bars broken
Her gates are fortified and bars strong
Her gates are open and welcoming
Her gates are guarded by angels
questions.correctAnswer: Her gates are sunk into the ground and bars broken
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes the gates sunk and bars broken, symbolizing vulnerability and defeat, consistent with Jeremiah 5:5, Ezekiel 12:12, Zechariah 2:5, and Revelation 21:25 where gates reflect the city's spiritual and physical security.

questions.question: Who are described as sitting upon the ground and keeping silence in Lamentations 2:10?
options: The elders of the daughter of Zion
The priests and prophets
The kings and princes
The foreign invaders
questions.correctAnswer: The elders of the daughter of Zion
questions.explanation: The elders represent the leadership and wisdom of the community mourning their calamity (Lamentations 2:10). This aligns with Job 12:12, Psalm 107:41, Proverbs 16:31, and Isaiah 3:4 where elders signify communal responsibility and grief.

questions.question: What is the nature of the lament in Lamentations 2:11 as expressed by the author?
options: Eyes fail with tears and liver is poured upon the earth
Joy and thanksgiving fill the heart
Hope and restoration are declared
Silence and meditation prevail
questions.correctAnswer: Eyes fail with tears and liver is poured upon the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 11 uses vivid imagery of deep anguish: eyes failing with tears and liver poured out, a Hebrew expression for intense sorrow (Psalm 42:3, Jeremiah 9:1, Ezekiel 2:10, Luke 19:41). It reflects the profound grief over the destruction of the people.

questions.question: What accusation is made against the prophets of Jerusalem in Lamentations 2:14?
options: They have seen vain and foolish things and not discovered iniquity
They have faithfully warned the people
They have predicted true restoration
They have led the people in worship
questions.correctAnswer: They have seen vain and foolish things and not discovered iniquity
questions.explanation: Verse 14 condemns the prophets for false visions and failure to reveal sin leading to captivity, highlighting prophetic failure (Jeremiah 23:16, Ezekiel 13:3, Micah 3:5, 2 Peter 2:1). This reflects the necessity of true prophetic revelation for repentance.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:15, what do passersby do to the daughter of Jerusalem?
options: Clap their hands, hiss, and wag their heads
Offer prayers and lamentations
Weep silently in respect
Ignore her plight
questions.correctAnswer: Clap their hands, hiss, and wag their heads
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes public scorn toward Jerusalem as the city once called 'The perfection of beauty' (Psalm 48:2, Isaiah 62:3, Ezekiel 16:14, Revelation 21:2). This public disdain underscores the consequences of sin and judgment.

questions.question: What is stated about the enemies' reaction to Jerusalem in Lamentations 2:16?
options: They have opened their mouth, hissed, and gnash their teeth in triumph
They mourned the city's destruction
They sought peace and reconciliation
They fled in fear of God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: They have opened their mouth, hissed, and gnash their teeth in triumph
questions.explanation: Verse 16 shows the enemies rejoicing and mocking Jerusalem's fall, fulfilling their desire to consume her, matching Psalm 35:16, Ezekiel 28:22, Nahum 3:19, and Luke 19:43-44 regarding enemy rejoicing over God's judgment on sin.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 2:17 say about the LORD's actions regarding His word and plans?
options: He has done and fulfilled what He devised and commanded
He has repented and withheld judgment
He has delayed His promises to Israel
He has changed His mind due to mercy
questions.correctAnswer: He has done and fulfilled what He devised and commanded
questions.explanation: Verse 17 affirms God's faithfulness to His word and plans in judgment, emphasizing divine sovereignty (Isaiah 14:24, Ezekiel 14:23, Psalm 33:11, Romans 11:29). God's decrees are sure, even in executing judgment.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:18, what is the heart of the daughter of Zion described as doing?
options: Crying unto the Lord and letting tears run like a river
Rejoicing in God's mercy
Remaining silent and still
Seeking political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Crying unto the Lord and letting tears run like a river
questions.explanation: Verse 18 portrays heartfelt, continuous lamentation before God, consistent with Psalm 126:5, Nehemiah 1:4, Joel 2:12-13, and John 11:35, where genuine sorrow leads to prayer and dependence on God.

questions.question: What plea is made in Lamentations 2:19 regarding the young children fainting from hunger?
options: To pour out the heart like water before the Lord and lift up hands for their life
To seek food from the nations
To abandon the city and flee
To prepare for battle
questions.correctAnswer: To pour out the heart like water before the Lord and lift up hands for their life
questions.explanation: Verse 19 calls for earnest prayer and intercession for the starving children, reflecting biblical principles of intercession and reliance on God (Psalm 28:2, Jeremiah 29:12, 1 Timothy 2:1, James 5:16). It underscores God's role as provider and sustainer.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:21, who lies slain in the streets, and by whose hand?
options: The young and old, virgins and young men, slain by the LORD in His anger
Only the foreign invaders, slain by the Israelites
The priests and prophets, slain by the people
None, the city was spared
questions.correctAnswer: The young and old, virgins and young men, slain by the LORD in His anger
questions.explanation: Verse 21 attributes the death of Israel's people to God's wrath, emphasizing divine judgment for sin (Exodus 32:35, 2 Samuel 24:15, Ezekiel 9:6, Romans 1:18). It highlights God's holiness and justice in punishing sin.
